text.b: Attention: Mr. Asad Yousfani, Project Manager
Reference: Barrhaven South Recreational Complex – 3500 Cambrian Road, Ottawa

page.text: We are pleased to submit the following Transportation Impact Study (TIS) in support of a site plan
The structure and format of this report follows the 2006 City of Ottawa Transportation Impact
Assessment (TIA) Guidelines for a TIS. A checklist of the documentation requirements as outlined
in Appendix C of the TIA guidelines is attached overleaf.
A .pdf version of this report and copies of the electronic software files are provided on the
enclosed disk. Please call if you have any questions as you complete your review.
Description of the development (include all of the following that are known at the time of the
Location relative to major elements of the existing transportation system (e.g., the site
is located in the southwest quadrant of the intersection of Main Street/ First Street, 600
metres from the Maple Street Rapid Transit Station);
Existing land uses or permitted use provisions in the Official Plan, Zoning By-law, etc.;
Proposed land uses and relevant planning regulations to be used in the analysis;
Proposed development size (building size, number of residential units, etc.) and
Proposed number of parking spaces (not relevant for Draft Plans of Subdivision); and
Proposed access points and type of access (full turns, right-in/ right-out, turning
Horizon years (include reference to phased development).
The TIS must include a key plan that shows the general location of the development in relation to
the surrounding area. The TIS must also provide a draft site plan of a suitable scale that shows the
general location of the development and the proposed access. If the proposed development/
redevelopment is to be constructed in phases, a description must be provided for each phase,
identifying the proposed timing of implementation.
Existing roads and ramps in the study area, including jurisdiction, classification, number
of lanes, and posted speed limit;
Existing intersections, indicating type of control, lane configurations, turning restrictions,
and any other relevant data (e.g., extraordinary lane widths, grades, etc.);
Existing access points to adjacent developments (both sides of all roads bordering the
Existing transit system, including stations and stops;
Existing on- and off-road bicycle facilities and pedestrian sidewalks and pathway
Major trip generators/ attractors within the Study Area should be indicated.
The TIS report must include: a context plan of a suitable scale that shows the general location of
the development, the proposed access locations and the existing conditions in the surrounding
area; figures documenting the existing travel demands by mode; and a summary of collisions for
the effected study area roads. A photographic inventory of the transportation network elements in
the vicinity of the proposed access points would be beneficial to staff in their review of the
Changes to the study area road network;
Future background system operations (V/C, LOS, queue lengths):
include figures documenting future background travel demands by mode for
include figures documenting forecasted site trip generation and assignment by
include figures documenting total future travel demands by mode for each
Total future system operations (V/C, LOS, queue lengths);
Operational/ safety assessment (e.g., sight line assessment where grades are an
Storage analysis for closely spaced intersections;
Pedestrian and bicycle network connections and continuity;

text.b: Mitigation Measures and Site Design Characteristics

page.text: The TIS must identify all mitigation measures required to offset network impacts from the
development. The CTS must also identify key site design features required to implement the
Official Plan and Transportation Master Plan policies regarding site development.
The TIS must include all of the following, where they are required by the subject development:
Location and timing of proposed changes to existing traffic controls at intersections
(e.g., new traffic signals, Stop signs, etc.);
Location and timing of new intersections, including proposed traffic control measures
Mitigation measures required to offset impacts on the surface and Rapid Transit
New or modified elements of the bicycle and pedestrian networks;
Proposed TDM features or programs to support the site development.
Functional Geometry – Cambrian Road Interim Design
Functional Geometry – Cambrian Road Ultimate Design
Cambrian Road Interim and Ultimate Design
Excerpts from the Barrhaven South CTS and
Stonebridge Golf Community Phases 10 to 12 TIS
MTO Warrants for Traffic Signal Control
The City of Ottawa is proposing a recreational complex at 3500 Cambrian Road in Ottawa. The
site has an area of 6.9 hectares (17.2 acres) and is located at the southeast corner of Greenbank
The Ottawa-Carleton Catholic School Board is proposing an elementary school immediately east
of the site. The Barrhaven Fire Station was recently constructed on the west portion of the site
and has two access points onto Greenbank Road.
The proposed recreational complex will consist of a two storey building with a gross floor area
, an outdoor sports field and on-site surface parking for 374
building will include two NHL sized ice pads with spectator seating, an indoor pool, a leisure pool, a
full size gymnasium, multi-purpose programming rooms, a fitness centre, change rooms, City
office space and other ancillary space. The main access is proposed on Cambrian Road and is
intended to be shared with the adjacent school site. A second shared access is proposed on
Greenbank Road via the southerly Fire Station driveway. A third access is proposed on Kilbirnie
Drive approximately 165 meters south of Cambrian Road.
The recreational complex is planned to open in August 2014 and the adjacent elementary school is
planned to open in September 2013. The intersections to be evaluated were confirmed with City
staff. The time periods for analysis include the weekday a.m., p.m. and Saturday peak hours.
Analysis has been completed for the 2014 opening year and a five year horizon of 2019.
Due to rapid residential development, the planned widening of Jockvale Road between the Jock
River and Cambrian Road has been advanced and is now scheduled to commence in 2012. The
widening will include a two-lane roundabout at the intersection of Jockvale Road and Cambrian
Road. Construction of the first two lanes (future eastbound lanes) of the planned ultimate four-
lane urban cross-section of Cambrian Road has also been advanced to 2012, in conjunction with
The Barrhaven South Community Transportation Study (BSCTS) was prepared in October 2010 to
serve as an update to the 2006 Barrhaven South Community Design Plan Transportation Master
Plan. The background growth assumptions of the subject study are consistent with those
identified in the BSCTS. Traffic generated by the adjacent future school site has been identified in
a Transportation Brief prepared in support of the school’s site plan application. Trips generated by
the proposed development have been estimated using peak hour rates identified in the Institute of
Transportation Engineers (ITE) Trip Generation Manual, 8th Edition. Total future traffic has been
calculated by adding the proposed site traffic, the adjacent school site traffic and the projected
Intersection capacity analysis was undertaken for the existing, projected background and total
traffic conditions. Provisions for non-auto travel modes were assessed, including access to local
pedestrian, bicycle and transit systems. The proposed on-site design was reviewed in terms of
vehicle access, on-site parking, and loading activities. Potential for community impacts and
conformance to TDM principles were also evaluated.
The main conclusions of this report are summarized as follows:
The eastbound left turn queue at the Jockvale Road/Cambrian Road/Golflinks Drive
intersection currently exceeds the existing storage length in the weekday a.m. peak. This
will be addressed by the future two-lane roundabout.
Based on projected traffic volumes, it appears that the ultimate four-lane cross-section of
Cambrian Road is not required by 2019. Monitoring of actual traffic growth is
recommended to determine the appropriate timeframe for implementation of the ultimate
A westbound left-turn lane is recommended at the proposed Cambrian Road shared
access. The west end of the school’s looped access should be located an additional 15
meters to the east to address potential operating concerns relating to the proximity of the
two accesses. The storage length/parallel portion of the recommended turn lane could
then be extended across both accesses.
Traffic signal control is not warranted at the Cambrian Road shared access or at the
The proposed development includes adequate provisions for non-auto travel modes,
including easy access to local pedestrian, bicycle, and transit systems.
On-site vehicle and bicycle parking will be provided in accordance with the requirements of
the Zoning and Traffic and Parking By-laws.
Garbage collection and loading activities will occur on-site at the east side of the building.
Based on trip distribution assumptions, 15% of site traffic may be expected to choose the
Kilbirnie Drive access. This amounts to an increase of 20 to 25 vehicle trips during peak
hours. The impact on Kilbirnie Drive is expected to be minimal.
The City of Ottawa is proposing a recreational complex at 3500 Cambrian Road in Ottawa. The
site has an area of 6.9 hectares (17.2 acres) and is located at the southeast corner of Greenbank
Road and Cambrian Road, as shown in Figure 1.
The site is located in Phases 10 to 12 of the Stonebridge Subdivision, which is currently under
construction. Single family homes and townhomes will be located north and south of the site. The
Half Moon Bay Subdivision borders the site to the west, on the opposite side of Greenbank Road.
The Ottawa-Carleton Catholic School Board is proposing an elementary school immediately east
The Barrhaven Fire Station was recently constructed on the west portion of the site and has a
, surface parking for 20 vehicles and two access points onto
Under the City of Ottawa’s Zoning By-Law, the site is designated as an L-2 Major Leisure Facility
Zone permitting a wide variety of uses including amusement park, community centre, community
garden, community health and resource centre, daycare, fairground, golf course, library, museum,
park, place of assembly, recreational and athletic facility, school, sports arena and theatre.
The proposed recreational complex will consist of a two storey building with a gross floor area
, an outdoor sports field and on-site surface parking for 368
building will include two NHL sized ice pads with spectator seating, an indoor pool, a leisure pool, a
full size gymnasium, multi-purpose programming rooms, a fitness centre, change rooms, City
office space and other ancillary space. The main access is proposed on Cambrian Road and is
intended to be shared with the adjacent school site. A second shared access is proposed on
Greenbank Road via the southerly Fire Station driveway. A third access is proposed on Kilbirnie
Drive approximately 165 meters south of Cambrian Road. The proposed site plan is shown in
The recreational complex is planned to open in August 2014 and the adjacent elementary school is
Capacity analysis of the local signalized and stop-controlled intersections has been completed
using the Synchro 8.0 software package. This software uses methodology from the 2000 and
2010 Highway Capacity Manual (HCM) published by the Transportation Research Board.
Capacity analysis of local roundabout intersections has been completed using SIDRA Intersection
3.2 software. This software is based on gap acceptance methodology and allows the user to alter
Intersection operating conditions are commonly described in terms of a Level of Service (LOS).
LOS is a quality measure of speed, freedom to manoeuvre, interruptions, comfort and
convenience. Letters are assigned to six levels with LOS ‘A’ representing optimal operating
conditions and LOS ‘F’ representing failing operating conditions.
The City of Ottawa has adopted criteria that directly relate the LOS of a signalized intersection to a
volume to capacity (v/c) ratio. Vehicle capacity is defined as the maximum number of vehicles that
can pass a given point during a specified period under prevailing traffic conditions. The City’s
The LOS for an unsignalized intersection is based on average control delay and is defined for
individual movements. Control delay includes initial deceleration, queue move-up time, stopped
time and final acceleration. The HCM presents the following criteria relating the LOS for individual
In this study, movements at signalized and unsignalized intersections have been evaluated in
terms of the LOS as defined in the above tables. The City of Ottawa standards require mitigation
measures in the form of additional lane capacity and/or signal timing adjustments where v/c ratios
exceed 0.90 except in the Urban Core where 1.0 is acceptable.
Other types of analysis undertaken to assess the transportation impacts of the proposed
assessment of provisions for non-auto travel modes, including access to local pedestrian,
review of on-site design including vehicle access, parking and loading/unloading facilities,
evaluation of potential community concerns including neighbourhood infiltration, parking
impacts, and conformance with Transportation Demand Management (TDM) principles.
The study area for this assessment was confirmed with City staff and includes the following
The selected time periods for analysis include the weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hours and a
Analysis has been completed for the 2014 opening year and a five year horizon of 2019.
Within the study limits, Cambrian Road is a two-lane arterial roadway with a rural cross section
and gravel shoulders. It runs in an east-west direction between Cedarview Road and Jockvale
Road. The City of Ottawa Official Plan (OP) indicates that Cambrian Road has a protected right-
of-way (ROW) of 37.5m. Cambrian Road is not a designated truck route. Cambrian Road has a
posted speed limit of 50 km/h, dropping to 40km/h as it approaches the Cambrian Road/Jockvale
Golflinks Drive extends east of Jockvale Road opposite Cambrian Road and is a two-lane collector
road with an urban cross section. Golflinks Drive has a posted speed of 40 km/h.
In the vicinity of the development, Greenbank Road is a two-lane arterial roadway with an urban
cross section. Between Jockvale Road and Prince of Wales Drive, the OP indicates that
Greenbank Road has a protected ROW of 41.5m. Greenbank Road has a posted speed of 60
km/h and is not classified as a truck route south of Jockvale Road.
Kilbirnie Drive is located east of the subject site and is a two-lane collector road with an urban
cross section and a north-south alignment. Kilbirnie Drive has a regulatory speed of 50 km/h as
governed by the Ontario Highway Traffic Act.
Tucana Way extends north of Cambrian Road opposite Kilbirnie Drive and is a two-lane local
roadway with an urban cross section.
Jockvale Road south of the Jock River is a two-lane arterial roadway with a rural cross section and
paved shoulders. This southern section of Jockvale Road is located east of the subject site and
runs in a north-west to south-east alignment between Greenbank Road and Prince of Wales Drive.
The protected ROW for Jockvale Road between Bren Maur Road and Prince of Wales Drive is
37.5m, as identified in the OP. Jockvale Road is a designated rural truck route and has a posted
The Cambrian Road/Greenbank Road intersection is a roundabout with single lane approaches on
all four legs of the intersection. Pedestrian crosswalks are provided across each approach.
The Cambrian Road/Kilbirnie Drive/Tucana Way intersection is unsignalized with all-way stop
control. There is a single lane approach on all four legs of the intersection, and no designated
The Cambrian Road/Jockvale Road/Golflinks Drive intersection is signalized with designated left
turn lanes provided on all four approaches. Pedestrian crosswalks and signals are provided at
A copy of the 2011 OC Transpo system map is included in Appendix A.
OC Transpo bus stop #0668 is located on the north-west corner of the Cambrian Road/Greenbank
Road intersection, on Cambrian Road. This stop receives regular service from route 177.
Bus stop #9086 is located on Cambrian Road at the Cambrian Road/Kilbirnie Drive/Tucana Way
intersection (south-east corner). This bus stop is serviced by the regular route 177. Bus stop
#2065 is located on Kilbirnie Drive at the Cambrian Road/Kilbirnie Drive/Tucana Way intersection
(south-west corner). This bus stop is serviced by the regular routes 171 and 177.
Bus stops #0624, #0746, and #0851 are located on Jockvale Road at the Cambrian
Road/Jockvale Road/Golflinks Drive intersection (north-west, north-east, and south-east corners,
Bus stop #0624 is serviced by the following OC Transpo routes:
Bus stop #0746 is serviced by the following OC Transpo routes:
Bus stop #0851 is serviced by the following OC Transpo routes:
Bus stop locations and route maps are provided in Appendix A.
The City of Ottawa’s Primary Urban Cycling network, identified in the Transportation Master Plan
(TMP), designates Cambrian Road, Greenbank Road south of Cambrian Road, and Jockvale
The City of Ottawa’s 2008 Ottawa Cycling Plan (OCP) identifies Cambrian Road as a Community
Cycling Route between Cedarview Drive and Jockvale Road. Currently there are no designated
cycling facilities along Cambrian Road, and the OCP proposes paved shoulders be constructed as
The OCP classifies Greenbank Road as a Spine or City-Wide Cycling Route. The OCP proposes
paved shoulders be provided on Greenbank Road from approximately Jock River to Prince of
Wales Drive as a Long Term project (2018-2028). There are currently no designated cycling
facilities along Greenbank Road south of Strandherd Drive.
Jockvale Road is classified as a Spine or City-Wide Cycling Route in the OCP. No designated
cycling facilities are currently provided along Jockvale Road between Greenbank Road and Prince
of Wales Drive, however paved shoulders are present north and south of Cambrian Road. The
OCP proposes a shared use lane on Jockvale Road north of Cambrian Road as a Short Term
project (2008-2018) and paved shoulders south of Cambrian Road as a Long Term project (2018-
From a site visit conducted in March 2012, the following pedestrian facilities were noted:
Concrete sidewalks are located on the east and west side of Greenbank Road, north of
Asphalt sidewalks are located on the east and west side of Greenbank Road, south of
A concrete sidewalk is located on the north side of Cambrian Road, west of Greenbank
Concrete sidewalks are provided along the east and west sides of Tucana Way and
Concrete sidewalks are located on the north and south sides of Golflinks Drive.
The 2009 City of Ottawa Pedestrian Master Plan (PMP) indicates that a sidewalk has been
requested on Jockvale Road north of Cambrian Road. Sidewalks are proposed in the PMP on
both sides of Jockvale Road south of Cambrian Road.
Eight-hour weekday traffic counts were completed by the City of Ottawa at the following
The City of Ottawa also completed a weekday three-hour traffic count during the AM peak hours at
Cambrian Road/Kilbirnie Drive/Tucana Way in June 2011.
In addition to the above counts, Novatech completed an eight-hour weekday traffic count at the
Cambrian Road/Kilbirnie Road intersection in March 2012, and the following five-hour Saturday
The above traffic counts are included in Appendix B.
Traffic at the Fire Station driveways has been estimated based on the following operational
Hours of operation include two 12-hr shifts, 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m.
Staff arrive and depart 6:30 to 7:30 a.m. and p.m.
Fire trucks exit the site via the northerly access
All other traffic enters/exits via the southerly access
A nominal volume of five vehicles per hour (vph) is assumed to enter/exit the southerly driveway
during the weekday a.m., p.m. and Saturday peak hours. The existing traffic volumes within the
study area are shown in Figure 3.
Historical collision data from the last three years was obtained from the City’s Public Works and
Service Department for the study area intersections. A copy of the historical collision data is
The data has been evaluated to determine if there are any identifiable collision patterns. The
Ottawa TIA Guidelines define a collision pattern as more than one collision at a roadway location
that involves similar directions and impact types. Further analysis may be warranted for
intersections with a pattern of six or more collisions for any one movement or a total of 33 or more
The following table provides a summary of the number of collisions reported at each study area
A total of four collisions were reported at the intersection of Cambrian Road/Greenbank Road.
The collisions consisted of a single vehicle impact, one angle impact, one rear-end impact and one
A total of one collision was reported at the intersection of Cambrian Road/Kilbirnie Drive/Tucana
Way. This collision was classified as an “other” type of impact and involved a transit bus reversing.
A total of seven collisions were reported at the intersection of Cambrian Road/Jockvale
Road/Golflinks Drive. The collisions consisted of two angle impacts, two rear-end impacts, a single
vehicle impact, a sideswipe impact and one other impact.
No intersections meet the City of Ottawa’s criteria for further analysis with respect to patterns or
The City of Ottawa’s 2008 Transportation Master Plan (TMP) identifies a need for the following
Greenbank Road – new four lane road from Jockvale Road to Cambrian Road including a
new bridge over the Jock River to accommodate growth within the Nepean South Urban
Jockvale Road – widen from two to four lanes between the Jock River and Prince of Wales
Drive to accommodate access and growth for development within the Nepean South Urban
Cambrian Road – widen from two to four lanes between the new Greenbank Road to
Jockvale Road to provide access to development in Barrhaven South
The TMP suggests that the above projects will be required to support Phase 2 (2016 – 2022)
Due to rapid residential development, the widening of Jockvale Road between the Jock River and
Cambrian Road has been advanced and is now scheduled to commence in 2012. The widening
will include a two-lane roundabout at the intersection of Jockvale Road and Cambrian Road.
Construction of the first two lanes (future eastbound lanes) of the four-lane cross-section of
Cambrian Road has also been advanced to 2012, in conjunction with the Jockvale Road widening.
The two-lane urbanization of Cambrian Road is intended to address current and future pedestrian
The capacity analysis presented in this report for the 2014 opening year is based on a two-lane
roundabout at the Jockvale Road/Cambrian Road/Golflinks Drive intersection. Capacity analysis
for the 2019 five year horizon is based on a four-lane divided cross section for Cambrian Road and
the implementation of the first two-lanes of new Greenbank Road north of Cambrian Road.
Preliminary interim and ultimate designs of the Cambrian Road urbanization and widening have
been provided by IBI for use in completing the engineering design of the proposed site. Plan
views are included in Appendix C.
The Barrhaven South Community Transportation Study (BSCTS) was prepared in October 2010 to
serve as an update to the 2006 Barrhaven South Community Design Plan Transportation Master
The BSCTS assumed that existing traffic on the Greenbank, Woodroffe, Jockvale/Longfields,
Merivale, and Prince of Wales corridors would increase by 35% between 2009 and 2031, which is
equivalent to an average annual rate of 1.6%. The study assumed that a high proportion of the
35% growth would materialize early in the planning horizon, as follows:
The BSCTS considered a total of 18 future land use developments within the Barrhaven South
area, including locations in Barrhaven West, the South Nepean Town Centre, Chapman Mills,
Barrhaven East, the Merivale Road South Business Park, Riverside South and Barrhaven South.
Similar growth progression assumptions were applied to the future land use developments in order
to generate 2031 ultimate and 2016 and 2022 interim traffic forecasts. Traffic forecasts were
developed for major area screenlines and key intersections including the Greenbank
Road/Cambrian Road and Jockvale Road/Cambrian Road/Golflinks Drive intersections. Copies of
the interim and ultimate forecasts are included in Appendix D.
The background growth assumptions of the subject study are consistent with those identified in the
BSCTS. The 2016 and 2022 interim traffic forecasts of the BSCTS have been compared to recent
traffic count data and pro-rated to estimate 2014 and 2019 background traffic volumes.
Buildout traffic volumes have been assumed on Tucana Way and Kilbirnie Drive based on the
Stonebridge Golf Community Phases 10 to 12 Transportation Impact Study (August 2007).
Excerpts are included in Appendix D.
Traffic generated by the adjacent future school site has been identified and assessed in a
Transportation Brief (February 1, 2012) prepared in support of the school’s site plan application.
The estimated site-generated traffic presented in the brief is summarized as follows for the
weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hours:

text.b: Table 2: Trip Generation – Adjacent Elementary School

page.text: The brief indicates that the School Board has a preference to maintain the option of keeping their
operation independent of the recreational complex. As shown in Figure 2, the School Board’s
proposed site plan includes a one-way looped bus access that connects internally with the school’s
parking lot and a future connection to the recreational complex access south of the school’s
A number of alternatives are considered in the brief for the proposed connection between the
looped access and the parking lot based on the two-lane Cambrian Road scenario, including:
No connection to the recreational complex driveway,
Connection to the recreational complex driveway with no parking lot entry from bus loop,
Connection to the recreational complex driveway with parking lot exit to bus loop, and
Connection to the recreational complex driveway with only emergency access to/from the
Two alternatives are considered for the four-lane Cambrian Road scenario including:
No connection to the recreational complex driveway (all movements are restricted to right
Connection to the recreational complex driveway (left turns to/from the school occur at the
The City planner responsible for reviewing both site plan applications has indicated that comments
will be provided to the School Board indicating that removal of the connection between the looped
access and the parking lot will be required following the construction of the Cambrian Road shared
access and the southerly connection to the school parking lot. The analysis presented in this
study is based on this understanding.
The assumed school trip distribution identified in the Transportation Brief is described as follows
(excerpts included in Appendix E for reference):
15% northeast quadrant (of the existing Greenbank Road/Cambrian Road intersection),
School trips generated in the weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hours are shown in Figure 4.
Background traffic projections were calculated by adding the pro-rated BSCTS projections with the
trips generated by the adjacent future school site. Background traffic projections for 2014 and
2019 are shown in Figures 5 and 6 the weekday a.m., p.m. and Saturday peaks.
Trips generated by the proposed development have been estimated using the Recreational
Community Center rate (Land Use Code 495) included in the Institute of Transportation Engineers
The trip generation surveys compiled in the ITE Trip Generation Manual record only vehicle trips,
and the sites surveyed are typically located in suburban locations in the United States where non-
auto modes of transportation typically have a modal share of 10% or less. For urban
developments where multiple modes of transportation are readily available, it is considered good
practice to express projected trip generation volumes in terms of person trips, instead of vehicle
trips. To convert the ITE vehicle trips to person trips, a vehicle occupancy factor and non-auto
A vehicle occupancy factor of 1.23 (taken from the 2005 TRANS Origin-Destination Survey report)
and a non-auto usage factor of 1.1 have been assumed for this assessment. Combining these
factors gives an overall vehicle trip to person trip adjustment factor of 1.35. This factor was
applied to the estimated number of vehicle trips as calculated using the ITE land use rate. The
resulting peak hour person trips are shown in the following table.
The number of auto, transit and non-auto mode trips was then estimated based on the total
number of person trips generated by the development.
The 2005 TRANS Origin-Destination Survey report identifies a modal share of 70% auto, 3%
transit, 27% non-auto for trips made within the South Nepean survey district in the p.m. peak
The BSCTS identifies a number of notable rapid transit improvements in the South Urban
Community that will support City plans to encourage an increased transit mode share including:
Southwest Transitway Extension (Fallowfield Station to South Nepean Town Centre);
Southwest Transitway Extension (South Nepean Town Centre to Barrhaven South);
Transitway link (South Nepean Town Centre to Riverside South Town Centre); and
LRT link (Riverside South Town Centre to Downtown Ottawa).
The BSCTS assumed a transit mode share of 23% for the 2031 ultimate traffic forecast; 15% for
the 2016 interim traffic forecast; and 19% for the 2022 interim traffic forecast. For this
assessment, a transit mode share of 15% has been assumed for total trips generated by the
proposed recreational complex in the 2014 opening year and five year horizon.
An estimate of site-generated trips by modal share is provided in the following table.

text.b: Table 4: Site-Generated Trips by Modal Share

page.text: The distribution of trips generated by the proposed recreational complex has been estimated
based on the projected peak hour travel patterns within the study area and is summarized as
10% to/from the north via Greenbank Road
5% to/from the north via Tucana Way
15% to/from the north via Jockvale Road
15% to/from the east via Golflinks Drive
15% to/from the south via Jockvale Road
10% to/from the south via Kilbirnie Drive
15% to/from the south via Greenbank Road
to/from the west via Cambrian Road
Following the new Greenbank Road realignment it is assumed that 10% of site-generated trips will
re-distribute from existing Greenbank Road north to Cambrian Road west.
All trips to/from the north or south via Greenbank Road have been assigned to the Greenbank
Road shared access. All trips to/from the west via Cambrian Road, to/from the north or south via
Jockvale Road, or to/from the east via Golflinks Drive have been assigned to the Cambrian Road
shared access. All trips to/from the north or south via Tucana Way or Kilbirnie Drive have been
assigned to the Kilbirnie Drive access.
Peak hour site traffic before and after the future Greenbank Road realignment is shown in Figures
Total traffic for 2014 and 2019 has been calculated by adding the peak hour site traffic with the
projected background traffic. The 2014 and 2019 total traffic volumes are shown in Figures 9 and
Intersection capacity analysis has been completed using Synchro 8.0 and SIDRA Intersection 3.2
software packages. Operating conditions at the signalized intersection of Jockvale Road and
Cambrian Road/Golflinks Drive have been evaluated in terms of the volume to capacity (v/c) ratio
and the corresponding Level of Service (LOS) as outlined in the City of Ottawa TIA Guidelines.
Operating conditions at the unsignalized study area intersections have been evaluated in terms of
delay and the corresponding LOS based on Highway Capacity Manual 2000 (HCM) criteria.
Mitigation measures in the form of additional lane capacity, intersection control modifications,
and/or traffic signal adjustments have been identified for movements with a LOS E or F.
Intersection capacity analysis has been completed for the existing traffic condition.
The analysis is based on existing lane configurations and traffic signal timing plans obtained from
The results of the analysis are summarized in the following table for the weekday a.m., p.m. and
Saturday peak hours. Detailed reports are included in Appendix F.
Movements at all study area intersections operate at a LOS B or better, which reflects acceptable
operating conditions according to City standards.
The a.m. peak analysis results show a queue length of 40 meters for the eastbound left turn at the
Jockvale Road/Cambrian Road/Golflinks Drive intersection, which exceeds the existing storage
length of 20 meters. The need for additional storage will be addressed when the new two-lane
Intersection capacity analysis has been completed for the projected 2014 background traffic
Based on the preliminary design as provided by IBI, a two-lane roundabout with an inscribed circle
diameter of 50 meters, a circulatory road width of 10 meters, and a southbound right-turn bypass
lane is assumed at the Jockvale Road/ Cambrian Road/ Golflinks Drive intersection for the 2014
opening year. The preliminary design also includes eastbound and westbound left turn lanes on
Cambrian Road at Kilbirnie Drive/Tucana Way, which are assumed for the 2014 capacity analysis.
The results of the analysis are summarized in the following table for the weekday a.m., p.m. and
Saturday peak hours. Detailed reports are included in Appendix F.
Movements at all study area intersections are expected to operate under acceptable conditions in
the 2014 weekday a.m., p.m. and Saturday peaks.
Maximum queue lengths of 25 meters are expected on the southbound approach of the
Greenbank Road/Cambrian Road intersection and the northbound approach of the Jockvale
Road/Cambrian Road/Golflinks Drive intersections in the weekday p.m. peak.
Intersection capacity analysis has been completed for the projected 2019 background traffic
A four-lane cross-section is assumed on Cambrian Road for the 2019 capacity analysis. Based on
the preliminary design, the ultimate configuration includes a two-lane roundabout at the existing
Greenbank Road/Cambrian Road intersection with an inscribed circle diameter of 50 meters and a
circulatory road width of 10 meters. Two-way stop control is assumed at the Cambrian
Road/Kilbirnie Drive/Tucana Way intersection with eastbound and westbound left turn lanes on
Cambrian Road and single lane approaches on Kilbirnie Drive and Tucana Way.
The results of the analysis are summarized in the following table for the weekday a.m., p.m. and
Saturday peak hours. Detailed reports are included in Appendix F.
Acceptable operating conditions continue to be expected in 2019 for movements at all study area
Based on the 2019 traffic projections it would appear that the additional capacity provided by the
ultimate four-lane cross-section of Cambrian Road is not required by 2019. Monitoring of actual
traffic growth is recommended to determine the appropriate timeframe for implementation of the
Intersection capacity analysis has been completed for the projected 2014 total traffic condition.
As noted for the projected background traffic condition, a two-lane roundabout at the Jockvale
Road/ Cambrian Road/ Golflinks Drive intersection and eastbound/westbound left turn lanes at the
Cambrian Road/Kilbirnie Drive/Tucana Way intersection are assumed for the 2014 capacity
The results of the analysis are summarized in the following table for the weekday a.m., p.m. and
Saturday peak hours. Detailed reports are included in Appendix F.
No significant impact is expected at any of the study area intersections as a result of site-
generated traffic in the 2014 opening year.
The weekday a.m. peak turning volume meets the MTO criteria for a dedicated westbound left-turn
lane at the Cambrian Road shared access. A copy of the left-turn storage lane graph is included
in Appendix G. Based on the number of vehicles likely to accumulate in two minutes, a storage
length of 25 meters is recommended. A taper length of 55 meters should be provided based on a
Based on the proposed site plan shown in Figure 2, the spacing between the Cambrian Road
shared access and the west end of the school’s looped bus access is 30 meters. The west end of
the looped access is within the limits of the recommended westbound left-turn lane which could
pose a safety concern in the interim when Cambrian Road is two lanes and undivided. The west
end of the looped access should be located an additional 15 meters to the east to address
potential operating concerns regarding the proximity of the two accesses. The storage
length/parallel portion of the recommended turn lane could then be extended across both
accesses, accommodating general site traffic turning left into the shared access and buses turning
left into the school site. Alternatively, an interim median could be extended across the west end of
the looped access restricting left turn movements until the divided four-lane cross-section is
implemented on Cambrian Road, however this option may be not desirable from the school’s
Functional geometry showing the recommended westbound left-turn lane extending across the
shared access and the west end of the looped access is shown in Figure 11.
Intersection capacity analysis has been completed for the projected 2019 total traffic condition.
As noted for the projected background traffic condition, a four-lane cross-section is assumed on
for the 2019 capacity analysis. Two-way stop control is assumed at the Cambrian Road/Kilbirnie
Drive/Tucana Way intersection with eastbound and westbound left turn lanes on Cambrian Road
and single lane approaches on Kilbirnie Drive and Tucana Way.
The results of the analysis are summarized in the following table for the weekday a.m., p.m. and
Saturday peak hours. Detailed reports are included in Appendix F.
All movements are expected to operate under acceptable conditions with the addition of site traffic
in 2019. As noted previously, there appears to be excess capacity along Cambrian Road based
on the projected peak hour volumes and a four-lane road cross-section.
While the above results indicate no requirement for traffic signal control at the shared Cambrian
Road access or at the Cambrian Road/Kilbirnie Drive/Tucana Way intersection, the MTO criteria
for traffic signal control were reviewed to determine the extent to which warrants are met. The
calculations were completed for a two-lane cross-section on Cambrian Road. The results show
that signals are only 22% warranted at the shared access and 60% warranted at the Cambrian
Road/Kilbirnie Drive/Tucana Way intersection. A copy of the calculations is included in Appendix
G. The Ontario Traffic Manual Book 12 suggests that when using projected traffic volumes the
warrants should be 120% satisfied in the case of existing intersections and 150% satisfied in the
case of a new intersection for traffic signals to be considered.
Functional geometry showing how the recommended westbound left-turn lane at the Cambrian
Road shared access can be accommodated by the ultimate four-lane design of Cambrian Road is
The two-lane urbanization of Cambrian Road will provide a much-needed pedestrian link between
the surrounding residential communities, the proposed development and the adjacent future
On-site sidewalks will be provided along both sides of all three driveways, the north and south
sides of the main parking area, at the main building entrance (southeast corner of the building)
and at building entrances on Greenbank Road and Cambrian Road. A north-south pathway is
proposed through the main parking area via a landscaped island connecting the adjacent school
site and the residential community to the south. On-site pathways will connect the proposed
sports field with the rest of the site and with the surrounding community.
The number of on-site bicycle parking spaces will meet or exceed the minimum requirements of
the City of Ottawa Zoning By-law. Bicycle parking will be located near the main building entrance
and near building entrances on Cambrian Road.
OC Transpo bus stop #0668 is within a walking distance of approximately 170 meters from the
This section provides a review of the on-site design in terms of vehicle access, on-site parking,
The proposed shared access on Cambrian Road is 160 meters east of Greenbank Road as
measured from the nearest edge of the access to the Greenbank Road right-of-way (ROW) limit.
This access will have a width of 9 meters. The Private Approach By-law requires a minimum
distance of three meters between a private approach and any property line unless the property
abuts only one public roadway and the width of the frontage does not allow the required offset.
Based on discussion with the City planner, the subject site and the adjacent school site are to be
considered as one institutional campus as originally parceled. On this basis, the minimum three
meter offset should not be applicable.
If the sites are considered as one campus, the Private Approach By-law requires a minimum
spacing of 60 meters between a two-way private approach and any other private approach to the
same property. As the connection between the looped access and the school’s parking lot is to be
removed upon construction of the shared access and southerly connection to the school’s parking
lot, the looped access should not be subject to the minimum spacing requirement of the by-law
since it will only serve bus traffic and not general site traffic.
The existing southerly access to the Fire Station is 165 meters south of Cambrian Road as
measured from the nearest edge of the access to the Cambrian Road ROW limit. The existing
access has a width of 8 meters. A one meter widening of this access (to the north) is proposed.
The new access to Kilbirnie Drive is 135 meters south of Cambrian Road as measured from the
nearest edge of the access to the Cambrian Road ROW limit. This access will have a width of 8.5
The site is located in Area C of Schedule 1 to the City of Ottawa Zoning By-law. On-site vehicle
parking will be provided in accordance with the requirements of the Zoning By-law.
The City of Ottawa Traffic and Parking By-law identifies a minimum requirement of four handicap
parking spaces for any public parking area with 300 to 399 vehicle parking spaces. A total of 6
handicap parking spaces will be provided at the east side of the building, satisfying the
requirement of the Traffic and Parking By-law.
A total of 374 vehicle parking spaces are proposed.
The Zoning By-law requires a minimum of 1 bicycle parking space per 1500 m
of 10 bicycle parking spaces. On-site bicycle parking will meet or exceed the requirements of the
Garbage collection and loading activities will occur on-site at the east side of the building.
The Zoning By-law identifies a requirement for two vehicle loading spaces for a GFA of 10,000 to
. Two loading spaces will be provided at the east side of the building as shown on the
Direct vehicle access to the main building entrance and parking area is provided via Cambrian
Road and Greenbank Road, both of which are classified as arterial roads. The Kilbirnie Drive
access connects with the rear of the parking area and has no direct connection to the main
building entrance. The intent of the Kilbirnie Drive access is to provide a vehicular connection to
the local residential community. The on-site circulation has been designed in such a way that
traffic using the adjacent arterial network will not be attracted to the Kilbirnie Drive access. Based
on the trip distribution assumptions outlined in Section 3.5, 15% of site generated traffic may be
expected to choose the Kilbirnie Drive access. This amounts to an increase of 20 to 25 vehicle
trips during peak hours. The site-related impact on Kilbirnie Drive is expected to be minimal.
On-site parking will be provided in accordance with the requirements of the Zoning By-law.
Parking infiltration onto area roadways is not anticipated.
The City of Ottawa is developing a comprehensive Transportation Demand Management (TDM)
strategy as part of its efforts to reduce automobile dependency. TDM measures can reduce
transportation infrastructure requirements by encouraging people to change their travel mode,
The proposed development conforms to the City’s TDM initiatives by providing easy access to the
local pedestrian, bicycle and transit systems as outlined in Section 5.0.
The main conclusions of this report are summarized as follows:

text.i: Périodes de pointe seulement, lun. au ven.
